title: 1998 AHSME Problem 19
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many triangles have area 10 and vertices at (-5,0),(5,0) and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(5\\cos \\theta, 5\\sin \\theta)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some angle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 2
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Letters A,B,C, and D represent four different digits selected from 0, 1, 2, ... , 9. If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\frac{ A+B}{C+D} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"is an integer that is as large as possible, what is the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simple logic..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = 9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B = 8"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A and B being the 2 largest numbers in the set"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C = 0"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D = 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C and D being the 2 smallest numbers in the set"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(C+D) = 1, so any number can be placed in replacement of A and B other than 0 and 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then, the highest possible is needed so the 2 largest numbers will replace A and B, numbers 8 and 9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So (A+B) = 17"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(8+9) / (0+1) = 17","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{17}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the answer"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The numerator is independent of the integer (practically), since the largest numbers will go in the numerator. You dont need to determine the denominator, or do any division.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey yo pals,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As the selected range of A,B,C & D are [0.9],"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as (A+B) / (C+D) = maximum possible value,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C+D = the lowest value, since for the lowest value of C+D=1,(C=0, D=1 or D=0, C=1),"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+ B / 1 = maximum possible value,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A + B = 8 + 9 = 17 as A = 8, B=9 or A=9, B=8 ,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"therefore, maximum possible value = 17,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"thanks....."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 20
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Three cards, each with a positive integer written on it, are lying face-down on a table. Casey, Stacy, and Tracy are told that"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a) the numbers are all different"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(b) they sum to 13"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(c) they are in increasing order, left to right"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, Casey looks at the number on the leftmost card and says, "I don't have enough information to determine the other two numbers." Then Tracy looks at the number on the rightmost card and says, "I don't have enough information to determine the other two numbers." Finally, Stacy looks at the number on the middle card and says, "I don't have enough information to determine the other two numbers." Assume that each person knows that the other two reason perfectly and hears their comments. What number is on the middle card?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
It\quad is\quad not\quad hard\quad to\quad check\quad that\quad there\quad are\quad only\quad 8\quad possible\quad outcomes,\quad which\quad are\\ (1,2,10),\quad (1,3,9),\quad (1,4,8),\quad (1,5,7)\\ (2,3,8),\quad (2,4,7),\quad (2,5,6)\\ (3,4,6)\\ \\ Casey's\quad IDK\quad rules\quad out\quad (3,4,6)\quad \\ because\quad only\quad 1\quad possible\quad outcome\quad with\quad 3\quad on\quad the\quad leftmost\quad card.\\ \\ Tracy's\quad IDK\quad rules\quad out\quad (2,5,6),\quad (1,2,10)\quad and\quad (1,3,9)\\ because\quad only\quad 1\quad possible\quad outcome\quad with\quad that\quad number\quad on\quad the\quad rightmost\quad card.\\ \\ Stacy's\quad IDK\quad rules\quad out\quad (1,5,7)\quad and\quad (2,3,8).\\ \\ The\quad remaining\quad possible\quad outcomes\quad (1,4,8)\quad and\quad (2,4,7)\quad both\quad have\quad 4\quad on\quad the\quad middle\quad card."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 21
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In an h-meter race, Sunny is exactly d meters ahead of Windy when Sunny finishes the race. The next time they race, Sunny sportingly starts d meters behind Windy, who is at the starting line. Both runners run at the same constant speed as they did in the first race. How many meters ahead is Sunny when Sunny finishes the second race?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) Any log with base x and number y can be written as [log(y)/log(x)]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) if you write the numbers in question in the above manner you will see the numerator as [log2 +log3 + log4+....log100"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3) denominator will be common log 100!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4) logA + logB + logC +...logZ = log( A"},{"type":"text","text":"B","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"C"},{"type":"text","text":"....","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"Z)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"5) therefore numerator = log (2"},{"type":"text","text":"3","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"4"},{"type":"text","text":"5.....","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"100) = log (100!)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"6)therefore its log (100!)/ Log(100!) = 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

mind explain in detail?

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 23
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The graphs of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 + y^2 = 4 + 12x + 6y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2 + y^2 = k + 4x + 12y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" intersect when k satisfies "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a \\le k \\le b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and for no other values of k. Find b-a."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The k can be determined easily if you intersect the first circle with the line that goes through both centers. After you get the points calculate the distance from the center of the second circle to those points. The distances are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the second circle the radius is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sqrt {  k} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=144"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 24
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Call a 7-digit telephone number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d_1d_2d_3-d_4d_5d_6d_7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" memorable if the prefix sequence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d_1d_2d_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is exactly the same as either of the sequences "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d_4d_5d_6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" or "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d_5d_6d_7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (possibly both). Assuming that each "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be any of the ten decimal digits "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0,1,2, \\ldots 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the number of difference memorable telephone numbers is"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 25
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A piece of graph paper is folded once so that (0,2) is matched with (4,0), and (7,3) is matched with (m,n). Find m+n."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
Let\quad point\quad A,\quad B,\quad C,\quad D\quad be\quad the\quad (0,2),\quad (4,0),\quad (7,3)\quad and\quad (m,n)\quad respectively.\\ \\ Step\quad 1:\quad To\quad find\quad the\quad reflection\quad line\\ Since\quad this\quad is\quad a\quad folding\quad problem,\quad the\quad points\quad can\quad be\quad treated\quad as\quad reflection\quad along\quad the\quad perpendicular\\ bisector\quad of\quad AB.\\ \\ By\quad using\quad the\quad point\quad A\quad and\quad B,\quad the\quad equation\quad of\quad perpendicular\quad bisector\quad of\quad AB\quad is\\ 2x-y-3=0\\ \\ Step\quad 2:\quad To\quad find\quad point\quad D\\ \\ Since\quad CD\quad is\quad parallel\quad to\quad AB,\quad we\quad have\\ -\frac { 1 }{ 2 } =\frac { 3-n }{ 7-m } \quad \cdots \cdots (1)\\ Since\quad the\quad mid-point\quad of\quad AB\quad passes\quad through\quad the\quad perpendicular\quad bisector\quad of\quad AB,\quad we\quad have\\ \frac { 2\left( 7+m \right)  }{ 2 } -\frac { 3+n }{ 2 } -3=0\quad \cdots \cdots (2)\\ By\quad solving\quad (1)\quad and\quad (2),\quad we\quad have\quad (m,n)=(\frac { 3 }{ 5 } ,\frac { 31 }{ 5 } )\\ 
"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 26
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In quadrilateral ABCD, it is given that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\angle A = 120^{\\circ}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", angles B and D are right angles, AB = 13, and AD = 46. Then AC="}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"http://s18.postimg.org/fl1y0tsjd/Untitled.png"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle B = \angle C = 90^{\circ},"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a diameter of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\circledcirc ABCD."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" By cosine rule on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle ABD,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we find out that
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BD= \sqrt{AB^2 + AD^2 - 2 \cdot AB \cdot AD \cdot \cos \angle A} = \sqrt{2883}. "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
By Sine rule on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle ABD,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{BD}{\sin \angle A} = AC \implies AC =  \dfrac{2 \sqrt{2883}}{\sqrt{3}} = \boxed{62}."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            It follows directly from the "Extended Sine Law" (see wiki) which relates a triangle to the radius of a circumscribed circle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I just learned about that now. I solved it from first principles and sum angle formula.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 27
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9 \\times 9 \\times 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cube is composed of twenty-seven "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \\times 3 \\times 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cubes. The big cube is ‘tunneled’ as follows: First the six "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \\times 3 \\times 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cubes which make up the center of each face as well as the center "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \\times 3 \\times 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cube are removed as shown. Second, each of the twenty remaining "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3 \\times 3 \\times 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cubes is diminished in the same way. That is, the center facial unit cubes as well as each center cube are removed. The surface area of the final figure is"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, we find the total surface area of each of the 3x3x3 cubes after they have been “diminished”. We will find it separately as the surface area on the outside and the surface area on the inside.
If you visualize this figure, it has eight 1x1x1 cubes on each face, so the surface area of each face is 8. So the total surface area "},{"type":"text","text":"on the outside","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is 8 x (1x1) per face x 6 faces = 48"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Each “hole” at the surface has four faces. The surface area on the inside is 4 x (1x1) = 4
There are six such holes. So total surface area "},{"type":"text","text":"on the inside","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is 4x6 = 24"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now 20 of these “diminished” 3x3x3 pieces are fitted together to form our final figure. When two pieces are fitted together, some surface area is lost from "},{"type":"text","text":"the outside portion","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" for both pieces. But the area from the inside portion is not lost like this."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have 8 corner pieces and 12 edge pieces. Corner pieces will lose (3/6) of their outside area because they are connected to other pieces on 3 out of 6 sides, while edge pieces will lose (2/6) of their outside area because they are connected to other pieces on 2 out of 6 sides. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, for corner pieces, area = 48 x (1 - 3/6) + 24 = 48
For edge pieces, area = 48 x (1 - 2/6) + 24 = 56"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Total surface area = 48x8 + 56x12 = 1056."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
